name: Building Community
Depends On: Readers should already be familiar with OSS as a concept, and would benefit from having experience as a contributor.
Learning Objectives: Good overview of what good project maintenance looks like. Briefly touches on kind of everything, but isn't trying to go into real about anything.
abstract: Discover how to foster a strong and inclusive community around your open source project. This guide covers effective communication, conflict resolution, and strategies to encourage contributor engagement and collaboration.
author: GitHub
description: Building a healthy community helps your project thrive. Learn how to foster collaboration and inclusivity.

name: Leadership and Governance
abstract: This guide outlines effective leadership and governance models for open source projects, emphasizing the importance of transparency, decision-making processes, and creating a structure that supports long-term project sustainability.
accessibilitySummary: These guides are available in over 20 languages, helping global communities learn and lead in open source.
author: GitHub
description: Effective leadership and governance ensure long-term success for your open source project.

name: Social Coding and Open Source Collaboration
Depends On: Readers should already be familiar with OSS as a concept
abstract: This lesson introduces the concept of social coding, covering how to collaborate effectively on open-source projects using GitHub, and how to engage with the developer community.
audience: Researchers, Open Source Contributors, Software Developers
author: CodeRefinery Team
competencyRequired: Basic understanding of Git and GitHub
description: This lesson explores social coding and open-source collaboration using platforms like GitHub. It covers contributing to projects, community engagement, and using social coding tools for collaborative development.
keywords: social coding, GitHub, open source, collaboration, developer community
mentions: GitHub, https://github.com, A platform for open source collaboration
teaches: The student will be able to collaborate on open source projects, contribute to GitHub repositories, and engage with the developer community.

name: Writing Documentation for Software Projects
Depends On: Requires Python! I recommend we link to this instead: https://www.writethedocs.org/guide/writing/beginners-guide-to-docs/
Learning Objectives:
Identify the role and benefits of documentation in research and software projects.
Describe different types of documentation (e.g., README, API reference, tutorials) and their purposes.
Recognize best practices for writing clear, accessible documentation.
List tools and formats commonly used for documentation (e.g., Markdown, reStructuredText, Sphinx).
Identify strategies for keeping documentation up to date.
Recognize how to involve community members in contributing to documentation.
Describe the relationship between documentation quality and project sustainability.
abstract: This tutorial covers best practices for writing documentation in software projects. It explains how to create clear, comprehensive, and user-friendly documentation using tools like Sphinx and Markdown.
author: Intersect Team, intersect@training.org
competencyRequired: Markdown, basic understanding of software development
description: This lesson teaches how to write effective software documentation, including API documentation, user guides, and installation instructions.
Notes: general but highly important to open source
keywords: documentation, Sphinx, Markdown, API documentation
mentions: Sphinx, https://www.sphinx-doc.org, A tool for generating documentation from reStructuredText.
teaches: The student will be able to write comprehensive documentation for software projects using Sphinx and Markdown.

name: Making Good Pull Requests
Learning Objectives:
Identify the purpose and workflow of a pull request (PR) in collaborative development.
Describe the key elements of a well-structured PR (e.g., clear description, relevant changes).
Recognize best practices for communicating effectively in PR discussions.
List common mistakes to avoid when submitting a PR.
Identify how to break large changes into smaller, reviewable PRs.
Describe the role of code review in improving quality and maintaining project standards.
Recognize the importance of linking PRs to related issues or documentation.
abstract: This tutorial explains how to create good pull requests (PRs) in collaborative software development. It covers best practices for writing clear PR descriptions, committing changes, and communicating with project maintainers.
audience: Developers, PhD Students, Open Source Contributors
author: Intersect Team, intersect@training.org
competencyRequired: Git, version control
description: This lesson covers how to create high-quality pull requests for open source projects and collaborative software development teams.
keywords: Git, pull requests, version control, collaboration
mentions: GitHub Pull Requests, https://github.com/pull-requests, GitHub's pull request feature
teaches: The student will be able to create clear and well-structured pull requests for software projects.

name: Issue Tracking with GitHub
Learning Objectives:
Identify the purpose of issue tracking in software and project management.
Describe common components of an issue (e.g., title, description, labels, assignee).
Recognize how to create clear, actionable issues.
List best practices for prioritizing and organizing issues.
Identify strategies for collaborating on issues within a team or community.
Describe how issue tracking supports project planning and sustainability.
Recognize the role of issue templates in standardizing contributions.
abstract: This tutorial introduces issue tracking for software development, focusing on using GitHub Issues to manage bugs, features, and project milestones.
author: Intersect Team, intersect@training.org
competencyRequired: GitHub, issue tracking systems
description: This lesson covers the basics of issue tracking for software projects, including how to create, manage, and close issues on GitHub.
keywords: GitHub, issue tracking, project management, bugs, features
mentions: GitHub Issues, https://github.com/features/issues, GitHub's issue tracking feature
teaches: The student will be able to manage issues in a software development project using GitHub Issues.

name: Collaborative Git for Teams
Depends On: 13—Intro to Git, 14—How to Contribute to Open Source
abstract: This lesson covers collaborative Git usage, including branching, merging, resolving conflicts, and setting up Git workflows for team collaboration.
author: CodeRefinery Team
competencyRequired: Git, version control
description: This lesson explains how to use Git for collaborative software development, focusing on advanced Git techniques such as branching, merging, and conflict resolution.
keywords: Git, version control, collaboration, branching, merging
mentions: GitHub, https://github.com, A popular platform for hosting Git repositories
teaches: The student will be able to use Git collaboratively, manage branches, resolve merge conflicts, and set up Git workflows for team projects.

name: Collaboration in Open Research Projects
Depends On: This covers literally all of the same content as we're linking to for all Community/Contributing sections and most of the Maintaining section. Should we position this as an all-in-one alternative to the other sort of piecemeal resources, or... ?
abstract: This lesson focuses on collaboration in open science and research projects, introducing best practices for working in teams, sharing code, and managing contributions using Git and GitHub.
audience: Researchers, Open Science Contributors, Software Developers
author: The Turing Way Team
competencyRequired: Basic understanding of Git, GitHub, and collaborative work in research
description: This lesson introduces collaboration in open research projects, focusing on using Git and GitHub to manage contributions, foster collaboration, and ensure transparency in research outputs.
keywords: collaboration, Git, GitHub, open science, research
mentions: GitHub, https://github.com, A platform for hosting and sharing research code and projects
teaches: The student will be able to use Git and GitHub for collaborative research, manage contributions, and follow best practices for open science.

name: Python Packaging
Learning Objectives:
Identify the purpose and benefits of packaging Python code.
Describe the basic structure of a Python package (e.g., __init__.py, setup.py, pyproject.toml).
Recognize the role of metadata in package distribution.
List common tools used for packaging (e.g., setuptools, pip, build, twine).
Describe how to write and organize code for packaging.
Identify best practices for versioning and dependency management.
Recognize how to build and distribute a package to the Python Package Index (PyPI).
abstract: This lesson teaches how to create and publish packages in Python. We assume a basic understanding of Python, and assume learners are comfortable using simple commands in a Bash shell.
author: The Carpentries Incubator
Notes: Pre-alpha lesson. Uses Carpentries lesson template.
keywords: english packaging pip python

name: Python Packaging for Beginners
abstract: This tutorial covers packaging Python projects for distribution. It introduces key tools such as setuptools and explains how to create packages and publish them on PyPI.
author: Intersect Team, intersect@training.org
competencyRequired: Python, setuptools
description: This lesson teaches the essential steps for packaging Python projects and publishing them on PyPI.
keywords: Python, setuptools, PyPI, packaging
mentions: PyPI, https://pypi.org, Python Packaging Index
teaches: The student will be able to package Python projects and upload them to PyPI.

name: R Packaging
Depends On: 49 - Intermediate R | 40 - R Basics | 13 - Introduction to Git
abstract: This workshop will provide you with the basics for writing your own packages in R.
author: The Carpentries Incubator
keywords: lesson-materials lessons-page best-practices r

name: Introduction to Git
abstract: This lesson introduces the basics of Git for version control, focusing on how to track changes, work with repositories, and manage a project‚Äôs history using Git.
author: CodeRefinery Team
competencyRequired: Basic understanding of the command line
description: This lesson introduces Git, a distributed version control system, and teaches how to use it to track changes, collaborate on projects, and manage the history of a codebase.
keywords: Git, version control, repositories, project management
mentions: GitHub, https://github.com, A platform for hosting Git repositories
teaches: The student will be able to use Git for version control, create and manage repositories, and track changes in a project.

name: How to Contribute to Open Source
abstract: This resource gives a broad overview of terms and processes important to understand as a new contributor. It also includes suggestions on how to find a project to contribute to.
Notes: Maybe not relevant for researchers, but useful for students as a self-guided entry point

name: Continuous Integration and Delivery with GitHub Actions
Learning Objectives:
Distinguish between Continuous Integration (CI), Continuous Delivery, and Continuous Deployment.
Identify types of "breaking changes" in different development contexts.
Define deployment in the context of CI/CD and recognize real-world examples.
Apply CI/CD principles to automate workflows beyond code testing (e.g., notifications, data fetching).
Explain why GitHub Actions may be preferred for CI/CD in open-source projects.
Configure a basic CI pipeline using GitHub Actions for code testing and packaging.
Use a matrix strategy in CI to test across multiple Python versions and platforms.
Automate both building and publishing artifacts—like Python packages—using GitHub Actions.
Add and configure status badges to visualize CI/CD workflow health.
abstract: This tutorial introduces continuous integration (CI) and continuous delivery (CD) practices in software development. It covers how to automate testing, building, and deployment using tools like GitHub Actions.
audience: Software Developers, PhD Students, DevOps Engineers
author: Intersect Team, intersect@training.org
competencyRequired: Git, CI/CD concepts, software development
description: This lesson covers how to set up continuous integration and continuous delivery pipelines for automated testing and deployment in software projects.
keywords: CI, CD, continuous integration, continuous delivery, GitHub Actions, automation
mentions: GitHub Actions, https://github.com/features/actions, Automation for CI/CD on GitHub
teaches: The student will be able to set up CI/CD pipelines for their projects and automate tests, builds, and deployments.

name: CI/CD for Research Software with GitLab CI
Depends On: 13 - Introduction to Git | 10 - Python Packaging | 17 - Unit Testing and TDD in Python
abstract: This lesson introduces Continuous Integration and Continuous Delivery (CI/CD) practices with a focus on research software. It covers tools such as GitLab CI and explains how to automate testing and deployment.
author: HSF Training Team
competencyRequired: Git, CI/CD concepts, research software development
description: This lesson covers the implementation of CI/CD pipelines in research software projects, focusing on automating tests, builds, and deployments using GitLab CI.
Notes: Duplicates Line 9 resource: "Continuous Integration and Delivery with GitHub Actions", plus adds content (maybe too much?) - one should be removed
keywords: CI/CD, GitLab CI, continuous integration, continuous delivery, research software
mentions: GitLab CI, https://about.gitlab.com/stages-devops-lifecycle/continuous-integration/, A CI/CD tool for automating tests and deployments.
teaches: The student will be able to set up and automate CI/CD pipelines for research software using GitLab CI.

name: Unit Testing and TDD in Python
Learning Objectives:
Identify the purpose and benefits of testing in software development.
Describe different types of tests (e.g., unit tests, integration tests, functional tests).
Recognize common testing frameworks and tools (e.g., pytest, unittest).
List best practices for writing clear, maintainable tests.
Identify how to run tests locally and in automated environments.
Describe how testing fits into continuous integration workflows.
Recognize the role of testing in improving software quality and sustainability.
abstract: This tutorial introduces software testing, focusing on unit testing and test-driven development (TDD) in Python. It explains how to write tests, run them, and integrate them into the development process.
audience: Software Developers, PhD Students, Open Source Contributors
author: Intersect Team, intersect@training.org
competencyRequired: Python, basic understanding of software development
description: This lesson covers how to write and run unit tests in Python, including an introduction to test-driven development (TDD) and its benefits.
keywords: testing, unit tests, Python, TDD
mentions: pytest, https://docs.pytest.org, A testing framework for Python
teaches: The student will be able to write and run unit tests in Python and understand the principles of test-driven development.

name: Effective Code Review
Learning Objectives:
Identify the purpose and benefits of code review in collaborative software development.
Describe the typical workflow for conducting a code review.
Recognize best practices for giving constructive, actionable feedback.
List common pitfalls to avoid when reviewing code.
Identify how to prepare code for review to facilitate efficient feedback.
Describe the role of code review in maintaining project standards and quality.
Recognize how to use code review tools effectively within version control platforms.
abstract: This tutorial covers the principles and practices of code review, focusing on collaborative software development. It explains how to conduct code reviews effectively, provide feedback, and integrate changes.
audience: Software Developers, PhD Students, Open Source Contributors
author: Intersect Team, intersect@training.org
competencyRequired: Git, collaborative coding
description: This lesson teaches best practices for conducting and participating in code reviews, emphasizing clear communication and collaborative problem solving.
keywords: code review, software development, feedback, Git
mentions: GitHub Code Review, https://github.com/features/code-review, GitHub's code review feature

name: Python Package Development Best Practices
Learning Objectives:
Use conda to create an environment and install packages.
Set up credentials for GitHub.
Explain Python package structure.
Use the CMS CookieCutter to build a Python package.
Explain the purpose of version control.
Introduce common git commands.
Understand how to create a commit.
Understand how to view diffs and see previous versions of files.
Explain reasons to use GitHub.
Learn about collaboration models.
Learn what a fork is on GitHub
Learn how to open a pull request
Learn how to raise exceptions.
Understand how to follow PEP8 style for Python.
Understand what docstrings are and why they are important.
Learn to write docstrings in numpy style.
Break code into modules and subpackages based on functionality.
Understand how the __init__.py file affects your Python package.
Learn about type hinting in Python.
Learn the syntax to utilize type hinting in Python.
Explain in-code documentation
Explain documentation tools like Read The Docs
Explain the overall structure of testing.
Explain the reasons why testing is important.
Understand how to write tests using the pytest framework.
Explain the concept and benefits of continuous integration.
Introduce the GitHub Marketplace as a one-stop shop for continuous integration services.
Demonstrate how to setup continuous integration using GitHub Actions.
Familiarize learners with YAML configuration files.
abstract: This lesson introduces best practices for developing Python packages, covering topics like structuring packages, writing tests, and managing dependencies for scientific software.
author: MolSSI Education Team
competencyRequired: Intermediate knowledge of Python and package management
description: This lesson covers best practices for building Python packages, focusing on scientific software. It explains how to structure packages, write tests, manage dependencies, and distribute packages via PyPI.
Notes: intermediate experience scripting in Python;  lesson for how to make their scripts into a software package.  Lesson built around best practices from MolSSI ( computational molecular science)
keywords: Python, packaging, best practices, dependencies, testing, PyPI
mentions: PyPI, https://pypi.org, A repository for Python packages
teaches: The student will be able to structure Python packages, write tests, manage dependencies, and publish scientific software packages on PyPI.

name: Building Better Research Software
Depends On:
10, 11, 23, 39 - This is a python based course
9, 13
36, 37

Course lists pre-requisites like version control in git and command line, but the course does cover the information with exercises for the student.
abstract: This short course is teaching tools and practices for producing and sharing quality, sustainable and FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable and Reusable) research software to support open and reproducible research. The course can be delivered over 2 full or 4 half days.
author: The Carpentries Incubator
keywords: english fair fair-software research-software

name: Reproducible Research
Depends On: No programming experience needed.  It would be best for a student who has experience with research papers and research projects and wants to detailed understanding of terms and concepts, but that is not necessary.
Learning Objectives:
Extremely comprehensive with detailed explanations on concepts related to Research Code, Data, LLM, Hardware.  It is not a class.  This would be useful as a resource for self sturdy for someone interested in get a overview of Research and  all aspects.  The examples illustrate the concepts but are detailed coding examples.  Students learn why Reproducible Research is important, policy issues around Reproducible Research, detailed definitions that are finely  parsed for different ascpects of research, use of git, licensing/IP discussions, research ethics, setting up pojects.
There are exercise using code provided for the class.
abstract: This lesson introduces the concept of reproducible research, explaining best practices and tools to ensure that scientific results can be replicated by others.
audience: Researchers, Open Science Contributors, Software Developers
author: The Turing Way Team
competencyRequired: Basic understanding of research methodologies and tools for reproducibility
description: This lesson covers the principles of reproducible research, including data management, version control, and the use of tools like Git to ensure that research can be replicated.
keywords: reproducible research, version control, data management, open science
mentions: Git, https://git-scm.com, A version control tool for ensuring reproducibility in research projects
teaches: The student will be able to apply best practices for reproducible research, including using Git for version control and managing research data.

name: Intermediate Research Software Development Skills (Python) Lesson Material
Depends On:
10, 11, 16, 17, 23, 48 - This is a python based course
9, 13
35, 37
Learning Objectives: This course is very coding/exercise based.  It meant to be practical course on how to construct reliable, readable, efficient research software in a collaborative environment. The course provides code examples demonstrating techniques followed by exercises.  Course is 8-10 half-day modules which is intensive and involves hands-on exercises.
abstract: This course aims to teach a core set of established, intermediate-level software development skills and best practices for working as part of a team in a research environment using Python as an example programming language (see detailed learning objectives below).
author: The Carpentries Incubator
Notes: Intermiediate python knowledge required; at minimum 6 months coding expereince.  Useful best practices for software dev.
keywords: training training-materials software-development carpentry-lesson python software-engineering-research intermediate software-design

Learning Objectives: Vey basic for someone with little to no knowledge about containers. Learn what a container is; how it differs from a VM

competencyRequired: Basic understanding of software development and command line usage
description: This lesson covers the fundamentals of Docker, including creating containers, managing Docker images, and using Docker for software reproducibility and deployment.
keywords: Docker, containers, reproducibility, software deployment, research
mentions: Docker Hub, https://hub.docker.com, A repository for sharing and managing Docker images
teaches: The student will be able to create, manage, and share Docker containers for software development and reproducible research.

name: Intermediate Python Development
Learning Objectives:
Inspect the structure and architecture of our software project.
Understand Model-View-Controller (MVC) architecture in software design and its use in our project.
Set up a Python virtual environment for our software project using venv and pip.
Run our software from the command line.
Set up a (virtual) development environment in an IDE
Use the IDE to run a Python script
Commit changes in a software project to a local repository and publish them in a remote repository on GitHub
Create branches for managing different threads of code development
Learn to use feature branch workflow to effectively collaborate with a team on a software project
Understand the benefits of following community coding conventions
Use code linting tools to verify a program’s adherence to a Python coding style convention.
Explain the reasons why testing is important
Describe the three main types of tests and what each are used for
Implement and run unit tests to verify the correct behaviour of program functions
Use parameterisation to automatically run tests over a set of inputs
Use code coverage to understand how much of our code is being tested using unit tests
Use continuous integration to automatically run unit tests and code coverage when changes are committed to a version control repository
Use a debugger to explore behaviour of a running program
Describe and identify edge and corner test cases and explain why they are important
Apply error handling and defensive programming techniques to improve robustness of a program
Describe the differences between writing code and engineering software.
Define the fundamental stages in a software development process.
Describe the different types of software requirements.
List the common aspects of software architecture and design.
Introduce appropriate abstractions to simplify code.
Understand the use of regressions tests to avoid breaking existing code when refactoring.
Analyse new code to identify Model, View, Controller aspects.
Understand the code review process and employ it to improve the quality of code.
Understand other documentation components and where they are useful
Describe the basic types of open source software licence
Describe the steps necessary for sharing Python code as installable packages.
Use established tools to track and manage software problems and enhancements in a team.
Conduct an assessment of software against suitability criteria
abstract: This lesson is designed to teach intermediate Python development skills, covering best practices in software development, such as packaging, testing, and version control.
author: Carpentries Incubator Team
competencyRequired: Basic Python programming skills
description: This lesson covers intermediate Python development skills such as writing reusable code, using virtual environments, testing with pytest, and managing dependencies.
keywords: Python, software development, testing, virtual environments, packaging
mentions: pytest, https://docs.pytest.org, A testing framework for Python
teaches: Intermediate skills in collaborative research software development, including version control, testing, packaging, documentation, and sustainable coding practices using Python.

name: Modular Programming with Python
Learning Objectives:
Know about pure functions (functions without side effects, functions which given same input always return same output).
Learn why and how to limit side effects of functions.
Discuss why and how to limit side effects of data. Also discuss when mutable data may be preferable.
Discuss why single-purpose functions are often preferred over multi-purpose functions.
Split-apply-combine, which lets you more easily parallelize. Make your code modular in a way that lets you split the steps and parallelize.
Understand how a command line interface to a code can improve usability and also make the code more versatile (to be combined with workflow management tools).
Connect modular code development to the remaining lessons (version control, testing, documentation, reusability).
abstract: This lesson introduces the concept of modular programming in Python. It covers how to structure code into reusable modules and how to organize and test these modules for better maintainability and collaboration.
author: CodeRefinery Team
competencyRequired: Basic understanding of Python programming
description: This lesson covers modular programming in Python, explaining how to write reusable code in modules, organize codebases, and test them to improve collaboration and maintainability.
keywords: modular programming, Python, software development, collaboration
mentions: pytest, https://docs.pytest.org, A testing framework for Python
teaches: The student will be able to write modular Python code, organize it into reusable components, and test it for maintainability and collaboration.

name: Testing and Test-Driven Development
abstract: This lesson introduces software testing, including automated testing, test-driven development, and unit testing, with a focus on Python.
author: CodeRefinery Team
competencyRequired: Python, basic understanding of software development
description: This lesson covers how to write tests for your code, understand test-driven development, and use testing frameworks like pytest in Python.
keywords: testing, test-driven development, Python, pytest
mentions: pytest, https://docs.pytest.org, Testing framework for Python
teaches: The student will be able to write unit tests and apply test-driven development practices using pytest.

name: Reproducible Computational Environments using Containers
abstract: This session aims to introduce the use of Docker containers with the goal of using them to effect reproducible computational environments. Such environments are useful for ensuring reproducible research outputs, for example.
author: The Carpentries Incubator
Notes: Keep - but it would also be nice to have something more general re: Codespaces, GitPod, VS Code devcontainers
keywords: docker english containers hacktoberfest

name: Understanding Software Licensing
Learning Objectives:
IMPORTANT. There is an error in categorization.  

It is a good primer that can be used as a lesson plan or for self study. Covers IP law, what licenses are, differenty types of licenses, links to choose license resources.
abstract: This tutorial introduces the basics of software licensing, focusing on open-source licenses. It explains the different types of licenses, their implications, and how to apply them to software projects.
audience: Developers, PhD Students, Open Source Contributors
author: Intersect Team, intersect@training.org
competencyRequired: Understanding of software development and open source concepts
description: This lesson provides an overview of common open-source software licenses, their conditions, and how to choose the right one for your project.
Notes: This is in Beta.  It has a lot of information. It's dense. I would like to reveiw final before allow external use.  It is a candidate but not approved for distribution.  This will need to be supplemented with UC Policies.
keywords: software licenses, open source, legal, GPL, MIT
mentions: GNU General Public License, https://www.gnu.org/licenses/gpl-3.0.en.html, A popular open-source license.
teaches: The student will be able to identify different types of software licenses and apply the correct license to their project.

name: Reproducibility Principles and Practices
abstract: There are myriad practices, often accompanied by software tools, that can help ensure research projects are reproducible. This overview workshop will help you decipher which to adopt and when to adopt them. The workshop also highlights additional benefits many of these practices confer, such as making it easier to collaborate with others. As an overview, this workshop is relatively non-technical, but provides technical references, including other DataLab workshops, for all of the practices covered.
author: Nick Ulle
